Great news! Yesterday a Texas court struck down the US Chamber of Commerce’s attempt to overturn a new Labor Department rule requiring retirement advisers to put their customers’ interests first. The decision affirms what we already knew: this conflict of interest rule was lawfully enacted and the rulemaking process took the views, costs, and benefits of all the stakeholders into account. Now President Trump needs to follow suit. He should stand up to the Chamber of Commerce — and the armies of lawyers and lobbyists that brought this frivolous lawsuit — and allow the rule to be implemented in April as planned.  Hardworking Americans saving for their retirement deserve to have a retirement adviser who is recommending the investments that are the best for their retirement security, not the ones that let advisers pocket kickbacks and prizes.

Tonight we will vote on Donald Trump’s choice for Secretary of Health and Human Services. This evening, I’m on the floor of the Senate, reading letters from families in Massachusetts who have seen the reckless, radical plans that President Trump, Congressman Price, and Republicans in Congress have put forth for the nation’s health care system. Listen in.

In the middle of the night tonight, the Senate will vote on Donald Trump’s choice for Secretary of Health and Human Services, Rep. Tom Price. Congressman Price has a LOT of experience in health care policy – experience trying to repeal the Affordable Care Act, privatize Medicare, defund Planned Parenthood, and gut Medicaid. And if that’s not bad enough, Rep. Price has been caught in a giant ethics scandal around buying and selling stocks connected to legislation he’s pushing. I spoke on the Senate floor tonight to urge my colleagues to vote NO on Tom Price for HHS.

Steve Mnuchin – Donald Trump’s choice for Treasury Secretary – spent 17 years at Goldman Sachs peddling the kinds of mortgage-backed securities that blew up our economy. Then he ran a bank that aggressively and sometimes illegally foreclosed on people’s homes. There’s nothing in Steve Mnuchin’s record to suggest that he could stand up to Wall Street – or that he’d even want to stand up to Wall Street. I’m speaking on the Senate floor now to read the stories of Mr. Mnuchin’s victims and urge my colleagues to vote NO on his Treasury nomination.

Yesterday, just two days after a federal court upheld a Labor Department rule to prevent retirement advisers from cheating their customers and draining their savings, the Trump Administration backtracked on their regulatory freeze and submitted a proposed regulation to delay the new rule for 180 days.   Let’s be clear about what this means. On his first full day in office, President Trump froze all new and pending regulations with a stroke of his pen. He froze rules to help people access health care. He stopped a rule to help out spouses of active service members who have been relocated, disabled, or killed. He even halted a rule that would have increased energy efficiency, reducing emissions and cutting your electricity bills. But he had no problem putting forward a rule to give financial advisers six more months to cheat hardworking Americans saving for their retirement.

Politico Magazine just published a horrifying story about hard-working Americans who have been seriously injured or killed because their employers ignored workplace safety standards. In one case, an explosion at a Mississippi shipyard killed two workers and burned another so badly that he was in a medically induced coma for 3 weeks. That company’s consequence for sending its workers into a “death trap”? An $87 million government contract to build a ship for the Navy.   Federal contractors who can’t keep their workers safe on the job shouldn’t get another dollar of taxpayer funding. Period. But just last week, Republicans in the House passed a resolution to overturn a rule requiring federal contractors to disclose three years of labor and health and safety violations. Now Mitch McConnell has said he wants the Senate to take it up soon. Senate Republicans should put forward legislation to protect the workers of federal contractors instead of making it easier for contractors to sweep these tragedies under the rug.

Far-right activist groups and their corporate donors spent millions to steal a Supreme Court nominee – then handed over a list with Neil Gorsuch’s name on it to Donald Trump so he could do his buddies a favor. Judge Gorsuch’s record shows that he clearly and consistently favors the interests of big corporations over workers, consumers and pretty much everyone else.  Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer met with Judge Gorsuch earlier this week. His concerns should worry everyone who cares about the independence of our courts.

During his 16-year tenure as the CEO of Carl’s Jr and Hardee’s, Andrew Puzder has made a fortune by squeezing his workers out of wages and benefits – the same workers he’d be charged with protecting as Secretary of Labor. And his company has an appalling record of labor law abuses and the most discrimination lawsuits of any major burger chain – the same labor laws he’d be charged with enforcing as Secretary of Labor.   I have a large number of concerns and questions I’d like Mr. Puzder to answer – and I doubt that the Republican Committee chairman will give me more a few minutes to ask them. So today I sent Mr. Puzder a 28-page letter with 83 questions about his readiness for the job and his qualifications to protect America’s workers.

Donald Trump promised to take on Wall Street, but since coming to office he’s done Wall Street’s bidding – attacking the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and starting to unwind the Labor Department’s conflicts-of-interest rule that would save working families $17 billion a year. Check out my interview on the President’s complete 180 on holding Wall Street accountable.
On Friday, the Senate unanimously passed my resolution congratulating the Patriots on their Super Bowl victory. Go Pats!
Donald Trump said that he would be tough on Wall Street. That’s a broken promise.

Donald Trump talked a big game about Wall Street – but he's hired enough Goldman Sachs alums to open a new bank branch at the White House.   Personnel is policy. Hiring Steve Mnuchin and all these Goldman Sachs executives shows that President Trump has no interest in reducing Wall Street’s influence. If Wall Street threatens to blow up the economy again, does anyone seriously expect Steve Mnuchin to tell his buddies to knock it off?   I will be voting NO on Steve Mnuchin’s confirmation tonight. I urge all of my colleagues to do the same.

Michael Flynn’s blinding religious hatred and shady Russian ties disqualified him as National Security Adviser on day one. His removal is a win for American values. But American national security demands that we not allow Michael Flynn to become a scapegoat for this Administration's disturbing ties to Russia.  This isn’t a game. Reports say the Russians conducted a series of successful cyber-attacks on our elections to help elect Donald Trump. Reports say our own intelligence agencies have corroborated parts of a dossier alleging that Russia has compromising information about Donald Trump. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has close ties to Putin. Commerce Secretary nominee Wilbur Ross has close financial ties to Putin buddies. Donald Trump is still making money overseas and may have financial ties to Russia. Nobody knows since he STILL won’t release his taxes.  This. Is. Not. Normal. President Trump owes the American people a full account of his Administration's dealings with Russia, both before and after the election. When did the White House know that Flynn lied? What other contacts with Russia occurred during the campaign? Who knew what? Who approved what?   Congress must pull its head out of the sand and launch a real, bipartisan, transparent inquiry into Russia. Our national security is at stake.

President Donald Trump claims that he’s trying to dismantle the Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform rules because it’s tough for his business buddies to borrow money. So I asked Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen if that was true – and the data do not back up President Trump. His economic advisers claim that capital requirements – the capital a bank must hold to withstand an economic crisis – prevents banks from lending money to businesses. So I asked Chair Yellen if that was true – and once again, the Trump Administration is wrong. His economic advisers claim that financial regulations put American banks at a competitive disadvantage to foreign banks. So I asked Chair Yellen if that was true – and once again, the Trump Administration is wrong. In fact, banks of all sizes are more profitable since Dodd-Frank was signed into law.     Donald Trump and his team of Goldman Sachs alums aren’t fooling anyone. They want to go back to the good ol’ days when bankers could recklessly gamble with our economy, knowing that they could get another taxpayer bailout if their bets didn’t pay off. We cannot afford to go down this road again.

Last week, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau stopped a scam that cost 9/11 first responders millions of dollars. Congress provided money to the heroes of 9/11 who rushed into the twin towers – firefighters, police officers, paramedics – to cover the costs of medical care. But a scam artist targeted these payments and pocketed millions of dollars that should have gone to people with cancer and other costly ailments. Without the CFPB, appalling scams like this could continue for years, taking money out of the pockets of working families. Just another reason why we need a strong, independent consumer agency.

For the past month, President Trump and the Republicans have been working around the clock to sabotage health care in America. Issue a vague executive order calling for waiving unspecified pieces of the Affordable Care Act: check. Talk endlessly about repealing health insurance for millions of Americans without producing a plan to help people get coverage: check. Pull down all the ads encouraging to people sign up for insurance: check.   Turns out, when you shut down ads, fewer people sign up. And now insurers are being forced to make tough calls. Humana announced today that they are pulling out of the health insurance marketplaces because they don’t have enough young, healthy people enrolling in their plans. President Trump and the Republicans should stop these reckless actions now before they hurt even more people who need health coverage.

If you can drive a military truck in combat, with hazardous cargo, at night, through a sandstorm, then you can drive a commercial truck on an interstate. If you can dock or anchor a 10,000 ton warship under extreme stress, you can do the same thing for a small commercial ship. We spend hundreds of millions to train our servicemembers to do highly skilled jobs, and they are the best at what they do. But too many still struggle to transition into civilian jobs because they don't have the right certifications and licenses – even when they’re being hired to do the exact same thing under much less taxing conditions.   We've made progress on this issue over the last few years, and I don’t want to lower civilian standards – but I don’t believe for one second that these individuals aren’t ready to do the equivalent civilian jobs the day they leave the military. They shouldn’t end up buried in paperwork or dump their money into a shady for-profit college to do it. Let’s fix this problem.

Donald Trump’s nominee for Labor Secretary – Carl’s Jr and Hardee’s CEO Andy Puzder – has made his fortune treating workers with total contempt. Reports say Puzder is tired of all the questions and may withdraw his nomination. I’m heading to the Senate floor now to call on Andy Puzder to do just that.   Donald Trump’s nominee for Budget Director also has contempt for working families. Issue by issue – Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security, student loans, Head Start – Congressman Mick Mulvaney will make the budget work for giant corporations and billionaires, not the American people. I’m also heading to the floor to urge my colleagues to vote NO on Rep. Mulvaney.

Very glad to meet with 20+ presidents and trustees of Massachusetts community colleges this afternoon. We discussed ways the federal government can support our community colleges and invest in Pell Grants for students. Glad to fight with them to make sure all Massachusetts students have an affordable college option.

This morning, I joined to hundreds of workers in front of the US Capitol – workers who fought their hearts out to stop Carl’s Jr/Hardee’s CEO Andrew Puzder’s nomination for Secretary of Labor. Some days, the good guys win. This is one of those days.

A few hours ago, a judge in Oklahoma ordered the release of thousands of emails about EPA nominee Scott Pruitt’s relationship with Big Oil. Republicans must be worried about what’s in those emails, because they’re jamming through his nomination tomorrow – just FOUR DAYS before the emails will be released! Those emails may show corruption – but we already know that Scott Pruitt always sides with the corporate polluters and has no business as head of the Environmental Protection Agency. I’m speaking on the Senate floor now to strongly oppose his nomination and to share the stories of Massachusetts residents who are worried about what his nomination means for our environment and our families.

Earlier this week, Senator Ted Cruz and several of his Republican colleagues introduced a bill to eliminate the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. This comes on the heels of Jeb Hensarling – the Republican Chairman of the House Financial Services Committee – penning an op-ed in the Wall Street Journal last week calling the CFPB a form of “tyranny” that has “eroded freedom” and “must go.”    When these Republicans rant and rave about the CFPB, I wonder if they have ever talked to anyone about the agency other than the big bank lobbyists that drop by their offices and fill their campaign coffers. I wonder, for instance, if they’ve talked to some of the servicemembers who have benefitted from the agency’s efforts to crack down on financial scams targeting members of the military and to provide financial education to servicemembers looking to make smart decisions for themselves and their families.   Senator Jack Reed – the top Democrat on the Senate Armed Services Committee – recently asked the senior enlisted advisor from each military service for their thoughts about the CFPB, and each of them praised the agency for the work it has done on behalf of the servicemembers they represent. Take a look at the video. Good luck to Senator Cruz, Congressman Hensarling, or anyone else who tries to tell any of these brave men, to their faces, that the CFPB should be eliminated.

The Affordable Care Act and Medicaid save lives and provide millions of Americans with the guarantee that they have coverage when they need it most. Last month, I met Alyce and her son Sam at a health care forum that I hosted here in the Senate. Alyce had coverage from an ACA plan when Sam was unexpectedly born with serious birth defects. Sam is a happy, healthy kid today, but Alyce is worried about what happens if Republicans decide to rip up coverage for her, Sam, and millions of Americans. I hope President Trump and the Republicans in Congress pay attention to Alyce’s story – and the stories of their constituents who are telling them that they depend on the Affordable Care Act and don’t want to see it flushed down the toilet.

This week, Wells Fargo announced that it fired four managers in connection with the massive fake accounts scandal that came to light last year. This is a small step in the right direction – but none the four people fired were senior executives. There is still a long way to go to hold individuals responsible for the widespread abuses and fraud that took place at Wells Fargo. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau did its part by slapping Wells Fargo with a record-breaking fine and ensuring that scammed customers will get their money back. Now we need the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department to step up, thoroughly investigate the scam, and hold any culpable senior executives accountable.

Back when I was campaigning for the Senate, I met a man in his 60s down near the South Shore. His skin looked leathery like someone who had spent years working outside, and he wore a frayed Vietnam vets cap. He asked flatly: "Yeah, you talk about building a future. But what about transgender? What about them?"  I’ll admit: I didn’t expect that question from him. But I replied exactly what I believe: "We build a future for all our children. And that means transgender children. All our children—no exceptions." He stared at me, and then he said: "Damn right." He explained that he had a grown son who was transgender. "In a million years you’ll never know the special kind of hell he has gone through."  I’ve never forgotten that man – and I’ve never forgotten his son.  Yesterday the Trump Administration cruelly said to millions of students, families, parents like that man from the South Shore that it won’t stand up for LGBTQ young people. They used one of the oldest and most pathetic excuses in the book – "let the states decide" – to allow discrimination against trans students. They cowardly made it easier for some of our country's most vulnerable students to get bullied and beat up in our schools.   The United States Constitution and our laws do not give states a free ride to discriminate or eliminate the rights we guarantee to all Americans. The Trump Administration must protect and defend the basic civil and human rights of all our students, regardless of their sexual orientation or gender identity.    We build a future for all of our children. No exceptions, President Trump.

Defense spending is not just about the overall price tag – it’s also about spending taxpayer dollars efficiently and eliminating waste. At a recent hearing on the defense budget, I asked experts how the federal government can spend its defense dollars smarter to effectively address modern threats, and about what steps the Pentagon can take to reduce wasteful and duplicative spending.

Massachusetts residents actually pay more in taxes than we get back in federal funds. But the federal funding we do get is now at risk because of Donald Trump’s unconstitutional Executive Order threatening to withhold all grants to states that refuse to be bullied into letting Trump override their local law enforcement decisions about immigrants. Today, Senator Ed Markey and I wrote to the people who lead – or are nominated to lead – 17 federal agencies that disburse grants to ask whether they intend to use this unconstitutional order to cut off funding for affordable housing, veterans nursing care, children’s health care, and other critical services for the people of Massachusetts.

Donald Trump’s nominee for Commerce Secretary – Wall Street billionaire Wilbur Ross – has seriously shady ties to Russia. He plans to keep making money from one of his major oil shipping companies while working as Commerce Secretary. He’s made billions off the backs of struggling homeowners. And in his free time he hangs out with other Wall Street tycoons who sit around making fun of everybody else. This is truly disgusting. For all of those reasons – for any of them, really – I urged my colleagues today to reject Mr. Ross’s nomination.

I can name about a zillion reasons why Massachusetts is the best state in the nation to live – but I’m glad we’re being recognized in particular for our top schools and health care system. Massachusetts knows that when we make the investments in our kids and all of our people, we build a stronger future for everyone. Go Massachusetts!

I’d like for you to meet my guest to President Trump’s speech to Congress tonight: UMass Dartmouth student and Iraqi refugee Tiba Faraj.   Like most of us, Tiba’s family’s came to America seeking a better life. Tiba’s father was shot and left permanently disabled while working for an American development organization. Her grandfather was killed. Her family later fled Iraq to Jordan, where they began the lengthy process of applying for refugee status. After an extensive screening process, they were granted admission to the United States in 2010 and settled in Lynn, Massachusetts. Tiba is now a college junior studying accounting, and last year she became an American citizen.   Donald Trump would rather spend his time hobnobbing at his resorts than looking into the eyes of the families who would be devastated by his policies. President Trump owes Tiba – and all Americans – an explanation for his reckless and unconstitutional agenda that won’t do a thing to help working families across the country. In fact, our strength as a country is rooted in our diversity. Tiba’s courage, resilience and optimism embody the very best of the American spirit – and her many contributions have made us that much stronger.

On Monday, the Justice Department turned its back on American voters by dropping a key argument in a lawsuit challenging one of the most discriminatory voter ID laws in the country. All voters, regardless of race, ethnicity, age, income, or political party should have the right to participate in the political process. The Justice Department’s decision to refuse to defend the right to the ballot is shameful.

The Trump administration has not put forward a single proposal to help Americans save for retirement and we didn’t hear a peep from the president about retirement security in last night’s address to Congress. But this morning, the Administration gave financial advisers with conflicts of interest two extra months to cheat Americans saving for their retirement – a delay that could cost hardworking Americans billions of dollars in lost savings.

It's a simple question from Congress: "Have you been in contact with anyone connected to any part of the Russian government about the 2016 election, either before or after Election Day?" Jeff Sessions answered "No." Turns out Sessions, a huge Trump booster and self-described campaign surrogate, met with the Russian Ambassador. Two months before the election. And now he's the Attorney General – the final say on the law enforcement investigation into potential ties between the Trump campaign and Russia? What a farce.   This is not normal. This is not fake news. This is a very real and serious threat to the national security of the United States. We need a special prosecutor totally independent of the AG. We need a real, bipartisan, transparent Congressional investigation into Russia. And we need the Attorney General – who should have never been confirmed in the first place – to resign.   We need it now.

I am relieved to see that federal authorities today arrested and charged a man who has been threatening Jewish communities in multiple states. I am appalled by the desecration of Jewish gravestones, the bomb threats against Jewish Community Centers, and all other forms of violence and intimidation against our Jewish communities in Massachusetts and across America. This disturbing rise in anti-Semitic incidents makes it more crucial than ever that we stand up to bigotry. There is no compromise here. In all its forms, we must fight back against threats and attacks on Jews, on other faith groups – on anyone. We will not give an inch on this. Not now. Not ever.

Our intelligence communities have concluded that the Russian government tried to help Donald Trump get elected, both through propaganda and covert cyber activity. It shouldn’t come as any surprise then that the Pentagon’s Defense Science Board recently concluded that our current cyber defensive systems aren’t fully capable of protecting us.  When it comes to nuclear weapons, our country has relied on a policy of deterrence to protect Americans’ security. But it seems clear than in the 21st century, we need cyber deterrence – not just defense, but deterrence – as well. We need to be very clear with anyone who wishes to do us harm: cyber-attacks and interference by foreign actors in our democratic processes are unacceptable.

This morning I met with the terrific doctors, nurses, and staff members of Lynn Community Health Center, which services 39,000 patients in one of the most underserved communities in Massachusetts. 90% of Lynn Community Health Center patients live at or below 200% of the poverty level – and these patients need the Affordable Care Act for access to affordable health insurance and expanded Medicaid. We cannot allow the Republicans to “repeal and run” – not for the people of Lynn, and not for millions of people across Massachusetts and around the country.

Many people with hearing loss can’t get the help they need because hearing aid costs are too high. That’s why Republican Senator Chuck Grassley and I proposed bipartisan legislation to remove unnecessary regulations and make certain types of hearing aids available over the counter, which will make them easier and cheaper to access. Senator Grassley and I wrote about this idea in the latest Journal of the American Medical Association – take a look.

The US government pays hundreds of billions of dollars to federal contractors – corporations that hire workers to do everything from securing nuclear waste to serving food at national parks. But some of the biggest corporations often underpay their workers and put their health and safety at risk. Today my office released a report that shows that of the top 100 federal contractors, 66 have been caught breaking wage-related labor laws, and more than a third of the country’s largest health and safety penalties since 2015 were issued to federal contractors.   But instead of addressing the problem, Republicans in Congress are voting today to make it easier for companies who have abused their workers to get massive contracts from the government. Today’s debate on the Fair Pay and Safe Workplaces Executive Order is about who Congress works for – hardworking Americans or giant contractors? I came to Washington to work for working families in Massachusetts and across the country, and I’ll be voting against rolling back these basic protections.

US taxpayers have the right to expect that the giant companies that receive federal contracts will follow the law – including worker protections. The Obama Administration issued a rule that forces any company that wants a government contract worth more than $500,000 to disclose any labor law violations from the previous three years. This rule only hits massive corporations that repeatedly steal workers’ wages or put their lives at risk. But tonight, the Senate Republicans are repealing that rule.     Who does this Congress work for – hardworking Americans who want their tax dollars spent responsibly, or the giant corporations that can’t even follow basic safety rules for their workers?

President Trump apparently believes that blocking slightly fewer spouses, children, students, professors, doctors and people fleeing terrorists from coming to the United States under his revised Muslim ban somehow makes the ban less illegal, immoral, illogical, and unconstitutional. He’s wrong. There is only one way for Trump to fix his dangerous and unlawful Executive Order: rescind it.

For years, the Republican-controlled Congress has done nothing to help the 55 million Americans who don’t have an employer-provided retirement plan save for their retirement. Because of this federal inaction, 7 states have passed legislation to provide retirement accounts to their constituents and 23 others are considering proposals.   But now Republicans in Congress are considering a resolution that would halt these state efforts, stripping coverage from the 15 million Americans that would likely benefit from the programs in these 7 states. Congress should step aside and let the hardworking Governors and State Treasurers continue their important efforts to solve our retirement crisis.

Republican Rep. Jason Chaffetz said that after the GOP guts the Affordable Care Act, people struggling to get coverage will be fine if they just give up "that new iPhone that they just love."    Republicans have been repeating a version of this lie since Reagan – that families are living the good life with government hand-outs and wasteful spending. I know that trick pretty well. It once fooled me, too.   Decades ago, when I was a young law professor, I had what I thought was a clever idea. I'd go take a look at thousands of court documents to find out why families were actually declaring bankruptcy. I was sure that my study would expose tons of people taking advantage of the system – going on shopping sprees at the mall, wasting money on giant TVs and fancy dinners, and then crying to the courts to save them from their own bad financial choices. It's a story Jason Chaffetz would've loved.    Only it wasn't true.   Two other professors and I collected piles of data on the actual families that were filing for bankruptcy. What we found was shocking. These folks weren't lazy cheats. They were hard-working people who sacrificed for their kids and hung on to their spot in the middle class by the very tips of their fingernails – right up until they just couldn’t make it any longer. For most of them, some combination of medical problems, job losses and family break ups turned their lives upside down.       Today, every middle class family in America knows how hard it is to hang on – even with both parents working, it’s hard to make ends meet in a world where wages are flat and with housing, education, and yes, health care costs going through the roof.   We need to do more, so much more, to address the financial squeeze that's crushing our families. But the Republican plan to gut the Affordable Care Act moves in exactly the wrong direction. If it passes, millions of these families will see their health costs skyrocket. Millions will lose coverage entirely for themselves or their kids.   And only in Republicans’ land of make-believe will everything be okay if people just buy fewer iPhones.

I stand in solidarity with women across the country who are participating in the International Women's Day "A Day Without A Woman" strike.   No day off for us in the Senate today. Can you imagine what bills the Senate Republicans would try to ram through if 16 Senate Democratic women skipped a day of work? But I promise you this: We won’t stop fighting for women, families, & working people – on International Women's Day or any other day.

What President in his right mind would suggest slashing funding for airport security, port security, and the Coast Guard? Donald Trump, apparently.   Trump's ridiculous plan to build a wall on the southern border is also outrageously expensive – and, surprise, Mexico isn't going to pay for it. So now the President is considering funding his pet project by cutting critical national security funding that actually keeps us safe.   President Trump can propose whatever he wants. But if he thinks Congress will actually go along with this nonsense, he should think again. Nobody – nobody – who takes the safety of the United States seriously will vote to cut actual security funding to help the President save face on a dumb idea.

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services oversees the administration of Medicare and Medicaid programs -- and also is in charge of implementing many parts of the Affordable Care Act. I've heard from people across Massachusetts and around the country who are terrified about the Republicans' plans to rip health care away from millions of people, and they need a champion at CMS who will fight for them. Seema Verma isn't that champion. I'm speaking tonight to urge my colleagues to listen to their voices of Massachusetts residents -- and their own -- and vote no on Seema Verma's confirmation for CMS administrator.
Anyone who cares about access to mental health care benefits under the Republican health plan needs to watch Congressman Joe Kennedy III's video right now.

In 2015, Republicans and Democrats came together to pass the Every Student Succeeds Act—a bipartisan law that got rid of No Child Left Behind and took critical steps towards making sure we’re building a future for all of our kids. When the Obama Administration wrote civil rights and accountability rules to enforce this new education law last year, everyone who works in public education agreed that they were necessary. They were ready to get to work for our kids.  But today, Congressional Republicans want to take a sledgehammer to these accountability rules just so that they can give a blank check to Betsy DeVos and make it easier for her to push her radical privatization agenda.   Handing this law over to an Education Secretary with no experience in public education without any accountability rules to guide how federal education dollars are spent is an insult to teachers, school leaders, and families everywhere. This is not a game. Congress should not play politics with the education of our children.

Washington Republicans have successfully convinced people who can never agree on anything – doctors, hospitals, health economists, even insurance companies! – that their rush job of a health care bill is a total disaster. And don't forget patient advocates, like the American Cancer Society and the AARP. They're appalled, too. But Republicans seem intent on plowing ahead anyway, pretending that down is up, left is right, and a health care bill that will destroy care and affordable coverage for millions is somehow not a catastrophe.     Seriously? What planet are these guys living on? Nobody sent us here to play politics with people's lives. It’s time to junk this cruel Trumpcare bill before massive numbers of Americans are hurt by it.

Donald Trump talked a big game about getting corruption out of government. But it looks like President Trump wants a bunch of tame prosecutors – the kind who will push Trump’s political agenda and who won’t investigate Trump himself or his scandal-ridden cabinet.  For nearly a decade, Preet Bharara served as the tough, independent-minded, top federal prosecutor in Manhattan – drawing praise from both Republicans and Democrats for fighting public corruption and taking on Wall Street. He also had federal law enforcement authority over Trump Tower. I guess that’s why the President breached protocol to try and call him, then broke his word that he would keep Bharara at his post and fired him.   President Trump fired Sally Yates – the acting Attorney General – who had refused to defend his unconstitutional Muslim ban and who had warned the White House that national security advisor Michael Flynn had lied about his contact with Russia. He also pushed hard for Attorney General Jeff Sessions, a Trump loyalist who lied to Congress about his contacts with the Russians. Now he’s clearing out anyone in the Justice Department who doesn’t get in line with the program.   But we still have the rule of law in the United States. Firing respected prosecutors won’t shut down ongoing law enforcement investigations. And the Senate, which confirms US Attorneys, will not allow the President to replace real prosecutors with more political cronies – not without a massive fight.

It’s obvious that Iran isn’t our friend. It sponsors terrorism, engages in human rights abuses, tests missiles, and takes other destabilizing actions. But one area where we’ve made real progress is the nuclear deal, which put a lid on Iran’s nuclear program and placed it under monitoring and inspections. Enforcing this deal is better than no deal at all, and even skeptics like Trump’s Secretary of Defense agree. Given what Iran is willing to do, I think it’s easier to counter its provocative actions if it has no nuclear weapon than it would be to keep Iran in check if the country could threaten the world with a nuclear bomb. So if we’re serious about reducing the threat of nuclear weapons, we need to enforce the Iran nuclear deal – not rip it up as Trump has threatened to do.

This morning I visited Manet Community Health Center in Quincy – a critical health service provider for 15,000 people a year in Norfolk and Plymouth Counties. The incredible doctors, nurses and staff at Manet and other community health centers are at the very heart of our country’s health care system, and they’re on the frontlines of public health crises like the opioid epidemic. Today I launched a survey of over 70 Massachusetts treatment facilities to learn more about the resources they need to treat patients with substance use disorders and mental health needs, and to better fight back against Republican efforts to gut those resources by repealing the Affordable Care Act and cutting Medicare and Medicaid.

President Trump and Speaker Ryan want to nearly double the number of uninsured people in the country by ripping health insurance away from a whopping 24 million people – rolling back years of progress in Massachusetts toward making sure people have health care. They’re willing to burn down our health care system by taking away coverage and making more than $800 billion in cuts to Medicaid in order to hand over tax cuts to millionaires. This CBO score makes clear that the Republican plan does not improve health care in America, and it should be withdrawn immediately.

Military personnel using social media to share intimate photographs of women service members without their consent is outrageous – but it’s not a new problem. Every time we shut one of these websites down, a new one pops up, and we’ll keep losing this game of digital whack-a-mole until we have better tools to prosecute these crimes and discourage this dishonorable conduct. This morning I asked General Neller, Commandant of the Marine Corps, what Congress should do – and what he will do – to make sure we never have to hold another one of these hearings again.

As we approach the sixth anniversary of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau opening its doors, take a few minutes to read this piece about the agency’s great work on everything from student loans to credit cards to mortgages. For every dollar of its budget, the agency has returned four dollars to the American people – more than $12 billion total, to more than 29 million Americans who were cheated. The agency has been effective and efficient – which is why the big banks, payday lenders, and their Republican allies in Congress are so eager to see the agency gutted. It’s up to all of us to fight back to protect the agency so that it can continue to hold cheaters accountable and put money back in the pockets of working families.

What kind of health care bill has as its central feature ripping insurance away from tens of millions of American citizens? Who thinks the central problem in America is that middle class families have too much health care coverage and that the richest people in America need the government to hand them more money? There's no other way to say it: this bill is just part of a Republican plan to help the rich get richer and kick dirt in everyone else's face.   Consider what this bill will do to families and to communities struggling with the opioid crisis. Ask any family trying to get treatment for a loved one who is addicted to drugs:  We already have an opioid treatment gap. Gutting the ACA is like shoving a stick of dynamite in the treatment gap and lighting the fuse. If the Republicans get their way, people will lose access to recovery services. People will die. Now is the time to stop this cruel bill in its tracks, before it hurts real people.  Now is the time to speak out about the importance of the ACA and Medicaid to you and your family.

Turns out, an illegal Muslim ban by another name is still an illegal Muslim ban. A federal court just blocked President Trump’s second attempt to implement this unconstitutional policy. That’s because it still does nothing to keep us safe, it’s still a recruiting tool for ISIS, and it’s still a betrayal of our values. With the President batting 0 for 2 against the Constitution, it’s long past time for this Administration to stop fighting the rule of law and start taking steps that might actually help and protect the American people.

In 2014, Massachusetts voters passed earned sick time to ensure that workers don’t have to choose between taking care of their health and putting food on the table. But 41 million Americans – almost a third of our entire workforce – don’t get paid sick days. Yesterday, I joined Senator Patty Murray and 27 other Democrats in the Senate to introduce the Healthy Families Act, which would allow workers to earn up to 7 sick days each year. This basic protection will ensure that hardworking Americans won’t have to put their paycheck on the line when they get sick or need to take a day off to take care of a sick kid or family member.

We’re not even two months into the Trump Administration and we're already knee-deep in FBI investigations and congressional inquiries into Trump officials’ shady ties to Russia. Senior officials have lied to Congress. A national security advisor has resigned in disgrace. And in the middle of all of it, unbelievably, Trump continues to consider lifting sanctions on Russia, even after they launched successful cyber-attacks to influence our elections. Yesterday, I discussed with experts about why that’s a terrible idea.

We had terrific office hours in Worcester this afternoon. I’m very glad so many people joined us to ask questions and share their concerns – and to discuss how we’re fighting for Massachusetts families in the Senate.

Massachusetts is the most Irish state in the country – due in no small part to the wave of Irish refugees who fled to America during Ireland’s great potato famine. Yesterday, Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny reminded President Trump that America has always been a country of immigrants, and it is that diversity that makes our country strong.   This St. Patrick’s Day, let’s remember: We will not turn our backs on refugees and immigrants. It is against the very foundations of our democracy.

In her first test as Secretary of Education of whether she will stand with student loan borrowers or with the student loan industry, Betsy DeVos gets a giant F.  Earlier this week, I wrote to Secretary DeVos and asked her to uphold Obama Administration policy that kept student loan collections agencies from charging sky-high fees — up to 16%! — on certain struggling student loan borrowers trying to climb out of default. This one was easy — just stand up for students who’ve fallen on hard times. But yesterday, she failed miserably and real Americans will suffer unnecessarily because of it. Yesterday's announcement proves once and for all that we cannot rely on this Education Department to put the interests of students ahead of banks, debt collectors, and the rest of the student loan industry.
Glad to answer as many questions as possible during our office hours at CityStage in Springfield this morning.

Education Secretary Betsy DeVos apparently thinks her job is to hand the Department of Education over to people who want to bilk students.  On Friday, I sent DeVos a letter asking why in the world two of her key aides are former for-profit college executives with massive and obvious conflicts of interest. That same day, one of those aides — Taylor Hansen — apparently resigned. But the damage has already been done. The day before my letter and his resignation, the Department announced that it would allow student loan companies to charge certain struggling borrowers outrageous collections fees — reversing a pro-borrower policy that was loudly opposed by Hansen's father, who just so happened to be the chief executive of the student loan company that sued the Department of Education about this policy.    Hansen's resignation means something. It means transparency, pressure, and activism work. But we're going to need a whole lot more of it from everybody if we have any hope of making the Department of Education work for students.

We don’t need another Supreme Court justice to help out giant corporations. We need a Supreme Court justice who will uphold equal justice for all – rich or poor, black or white, female or male, gay or straight, popular or unpopular. Read my op-ed in the Boston Globe about why Judge Neil Gorsuch’s record shows that he is not that nominee.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is a tough watchdog for working families in Washington, forcing big banks to return more than $12 billion to people they cheated. That’s exactly why the CFPB is widely popular with the American people – and widely hated by Wall Street. Right now, House Republicans are holding a hearing about “restructuring” the agency – which is just another way of saying they want to weaken the CFPB’s ability to stand up for consumers. Instead of siding with the big banks, payday lenders, and debt collectors, Republicans in Congress should join Democrats in ensuring the CFPB remains a strong cop on the beat protecting families.

We’re days away from Republicans in Congress trying to ram through a bill that will rip health insurance away from 24 million people. This morning, the Senate’s Health Committee finally held a hearing... on the Food and Drug Administration policy. Seriously?   FDA is powerfully important, and I’ve spent years fighting to improve that agency. I’ll keep doing it. But it is absolutely nuts to just pretend the imminent effort to gut American health care isn’t happening and go on with business as usual. That’s what I told the Committee today.
Massachusetts Secretary of State Galvin is right to be worried: Donald Trump's bigotry and hate could greatly influence our census results.

Imagine what it’d be like if you couldn’t hear well enough to carry on a meaningful conversation with someone, or to talk on the phone. It’s devastating, and is related to social isolation, depression, and even dementia. 48 million Americans – including half of all seniors! – have some hearing loss, but the vast majority of them don’t even use hearing aids, because they’re simply too expensive. Yesterday, I introduced bipartisan legislation with Republican Senator Grassley and others to direct the FDA to allow for over-the-counter sales of hearing aids. With all the problems we have right now, this one should be a no-brainer. If we do it right, we can dramatically lower costs and make life so much better for millions of Americans.

The test for Secretary of Labor is simple: will you stand up for 150 million American workers? This morning, Donald Trump’s nominee Alex Acosta wouldn’t give me straight answers to easy questions about whether he’ll fight to protect the health, safety, paychecks, and retirement savings of American workers. If he can’t commit to putting workers first, then he shouldn’t be the Labor Secretary.

Out of all the people President Trump could’ve selected to run the SEC, he picked Jay Clayton – a big Wall Street lawyer who is barred under ethics rules from voting to punish any of his former clients, including Goldman Sachs, Barclays, and other huge banks. That’s a big deal because the SEC Chairman’s vote can determine whether an enforcement action goes forward – and a big bank is held accountable – or stalls. Mr. Clayton was quite clear today that he cannot vote to enforce the law against some of Wall Street’s biggest repeat offenders. That’s unacceptable for an SEC Chairman.

America’s middle class is under attack – and one big reason is corporations chasing quick profits at the expense of their workers. We saw that in Massachusetts two years ago when Cisco laid off 180 Boxborough workers as it continued to spend billions of dollars in stock buybacks to boost its share price.  I wrote an op-ed with Indiana Senator Joe Donnelly about how the SEC could help shift the focus back to innovation and reinvestment in our companies and workers – if we have an SEC Chairman who is looking out for working families.

Massachusetts passed bipartisan health care reform years before the Affordable Care Act, but national reform gave the Commonwealth new tools to expand coverage, improve care, and lower costs. Today, 97% of Massachusetts residents have health insurance – the highest rate in the country. The Republican plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act will roll back that decade of progress that we’ve made.  Members of the Massachusetts delegation and I asked over 100 organizations, providers, and families across our health system to share their stories about health care in the Commonwealth. This 180-page report sends a clear message: High-quality, affordable health coverage matters in Massachusetts – and we’re not going to let Republicans rip it away.

An increasing number of grandparents in Massachusetts are raising their grandchildren as a result of the opioid epidemic. I've seen the impact of this crisis across the state. At a recent Senate Aging Committee hearing, I highlighted the Adolescent Substance Abuse Program at Boston Children’s Hospital, which brings together pediatricians, social workers, and child psychiatrists to provide substance use disorder treatment to young people in Massachusetts and their families - whether parents, grandparents, or other caregivers.  Witnesses also told the committee how important it was that families battling substance use disorder have access to health coverage. If Republicans want to help grandparents and their families, they can start by scrapping their plan to rip health insurance away from 24 million people by repealing the Affordable Care Act and gutting Medicaid.

Glad to join Senator Ed Markey, Mayor Jon Mitchell, and our local leaders at the Port of New Bedford for a terrific discussion and tour of their lobster and scallops facility. The port is an economic engine, and I'll continue to fight for our fishing communities.
Tonight I'm having a town hall at Framingham State University to answer questions about what's going on in Washington and how I'm fighting for Massachusetts families. Watch live!
Tonight I'm having a town hall at Framingham State University to answer questions about what's going on in Washington and how I'm fighting for Massachusetts families. Watch live!

Donald Trump’s plan to kick 24 million people off their health insurance may have gone up in flames, but the President is just getting started. He’s made it perfectly clear that he plans to use his executive authority to sabotage Americans’ health care to try and score political points.   A legitimate president doesn’t pound his chest about sabotaging the health and security of the American people because it’s politically expedient. The American people know the difference between a fireman and an arsonist – and if this President keeps playing politics with millions of lives, they will once again rise up to fight it.

Despite all his tough talk about Wall Street on the campaign trail, Donald Trump followed the standard Republican playbook the second he came to office - loading the White House and the Treasury Department with Wall Street bankers and pressing for wholesale deregulation of big banks. It's no wonder bank lobbyists are feeling "emboldened" and chest-thumping about how they don't "just want a seat at the table" - they "want the table." Despite literally record profits for the banking industry, these lobbyists won't rest until Congress has gutted the critical financial reforms we put in place after the 2008 financial crisis. It's up to all of us to fight back and protect the rules that will help stop another devastating financial meltdown.

As a businessman, Donald Trump routinely stiffed the painters, plumbers, and construction workers who built his golf courses and casinos. So surprise, surprise: Yesterday, President Trump signed into law a provision that makes it easier for big companies that get giant, taxpayer-funded government contracts to steal wages from employees and injure workers without admitting responsibility.   Americans don’t need another guy in Washington fighting for big corporations, Mr. President. They need someone fighting to level the playing field.

Insider trading is a crime. You can end up in jail. Does anybody in the Trump Administration care? Carl Icahn continues to own billions – billions! – in investments in public companies like oil refiners and pharmaceutical manufacturers, while at the same time serving as President Trump’s “special adviser” on how to roll back federal rules whose repeal could drive the value of those exact same companies sky-high. It’s a blatant recipe for corruption, and last week, I asked Jay Clayton – Trump’s nominee to run the Securities and Exchange Commission – whether he will look into it. Here’s what he said.

Big Oil’s Administrator Scott Pruitt and President Trump took the first steps to unravel the Clean Power Plan – the Obama Administration's rules on dirty power plants. Let’s be clear about what they are doing. They are putting short-term corporate profits over the health of our children, the future of our farmers, and the security of our coastal communities.    The effects of man-made climate change are all around us. We need leadership that boldly fights for our children’s future. We need bold leadership that is willing to unleash the smart, creative, unrelenting spirit of our American workforce to tackle the threat of climate change head-on – because that is what American leadership looks like. Not the empty false narratives of President Trump.
I #StandWithPP because millions of women in Massachusetts & across this country depend on Planned Parenthood for basic medical care. #PinkOut

A shadowy Chinese company was considering investing billions of dollars in the renovation of a Manhattan office building owned by the family of President Trump's son-in-law and senior White House adviser Jared Kushner. That Anbang-Kushner deal raised ethics and national security concerns, so my colleagues and I wrote to Treasury Secretary Mnuchin last week about this transaction.  Good news: Today, the deal got called off. Even for the Trump Administration, this conflict of interest was way too obvious and way too dangerous. When we speak out and make our concerns heard, we can make a difference – and we need to keep doing it.

55 million Americans don’t have access to a workplace-sponsored retirement account. For years, the Republican-controlled Congress did nothing – so states and cities started passing legislation to provide for those accounts. Today, for some crazy reason, the Senate Republicans are voting to overturn the rules that allow for those retirement plans. For a party that loves to use “states’ and local rights” as an excuse to restrict voting rights and regulate women’s bodies, why on Earth are they making it harder for cities to help their residents save for retirement? Three words: Big business lobbyists.

The right-wing attack on women’s health care isn’t limited to Congress. In states all across the country, Republicans have been pulling political shenanigans to shut down women’s health care centers. Today, Congress is trying to make it easier for states to cherry pick which health centers receive Title X funding – a bipartisan federal grant program that provides birth control, cancer screenings and HIV testing to millions of women and men each year. This attack on Title X is so unpopular that not even a majority of Republican Senators would support it – Vice President Mike Pence had to cast a deciding vote to put this Republican plan in motion.   I strongly support the Title X program, and I stand with the millions of American women who are sick of Republicans playing politics with basic medical care for women. Watch me tell Republicans that enough is enough: back off Title X, and back off our health care.

Giant big box retailers shouldn’t be turning a blind eye to the subpoverty wages and predatory employment contracts of the truck drivers in their supply chains just so they can keep costs down and profits soaring. It’s reckless, cruel, and immoral. That’s why I joined Senators Sherrod Brown, Dianne Feinstein, and Kamala Harris in sending a letter to the CEOs of 16 major retailers to ask them to cancel their contracts with port trucking companies that abuse workers. The hardworking men and women who deliver the goods that keep our economy running deserve better, and these CEOs have the power to put a stop to these abuses.

Education Secretary Betsy DeVos had a plan to hand over the entire trillion-dollar federal student loan portfolio to just one private company to administer. Eliminating competition would make it tougher to hold this student loan company accountable. We’ve seen “Too Big to Fail” banks – the last thing we need is a “Too Big to Fail” student loan federal contractor. That’s why I worked with Senators Roy Blunt, Jeanne Shaheen, and James Lankford on bipartisan legislation to prevent this terrible plan from going into effect.   Today the Education Department announced that it will reverse its single loan servicer plan – and I’m glad that they are changing course. But it will be important to continue watching the Education Department and Betsy DeVos to evaluate whether its decisions are good for the millions of struggling student loan borrowers. Congress should pass our bipartisan legislation to ensure that the Department never heads in this direction again

Wells Fargo is a mess. On top of opening millions of fake accounts, it charged almost a million people for auto insurance they didn't want. Yesterday, my Democratic colleagues on the Senate Banking Committee and I asked for a hearing with the Wells Fargo CEO and Board Chair.   Even with Wells Fargo cheating its customers left and right, Republicans in Congress want to roll back the rules and shield big banks from accountability. Rather than weakening the rules on Wells Fargo, Congress should root out all the fraud at the bank and hold the right people accountable.

Attorney General Jeff Sessions’ latest effort to twist and distort federal civil rights laws perverts the goals of the Justice Department. This is exactly why he should have never been confirmed as Attorney General.

Despite all the commotion, drama and disorganization of the Trump Administration and Republicans in Congress, there’s one thing they’ve carried out with complete precision: A comprehensive, all-out assault on American workers. Yesterday, they socked it to American workers one more time before the summer recess: Confirming an anti-worker nominee to the federal agency responsible for protecting the legal rights of workers to bargain for higher wages and better working conditions. I voted against Marvin Kaplan for the NLRB – and I reminded my colleagues why hardworking Americans need an NLRB that’s on their side.

Huge news today for the millions of Americans with untreated hearing loss who can't afford pricey hearing aids. Back in March, I introduced legislation to drive down the cost of hearing aids for tens of millions of Americans by loosening up outdated regulations and making certain types of hearing aids available over the counter. I rounded up a bunch of Democratic and Republican cosponsors – equal numbers of each – to see if we could get this done. Consumer advocates, hearing loss groups, audiologists, and the AARP all threw their support behind the bill.    And today, the Senate approved the bill and sent it to the President's desk! This is good news for the millions of Americans shelling out nearly $5,000 a pair for hearing aids, and the millions more who go without help because they can't afford these life-changing devices. Because of bipartisan leadership in the Senate, we’re going to help a lot of people.

After World War II, our grateful nation offered returning soldiers the first GI Bill to help them get a college education. I was very glad to be an original cosponsor of bipartisan legislation that Congress just passed to modernize and expand the GI Bill again. This legislation includes several provisions that I fought hard for to help vets in Massachusetts, including expanded eligibility for Purple Heart recipients previously shut out of the GI Bill, better Yellow Ribbon educational benefits for families of fallen service members, increased coverage for some reservists, and restored benefits for vets who were cheated by Corinthian Colleges and ITT Tech. President Trump should immediately sign this legislation into law.

We had a wonderfully thoughtful 10th town hall of the year in Revere last night with Rep. Katherine Clark and State Senator Joe Boncore. I'm grateful to everyone who spent a Friday night in August talking about how we build a future for our kids and grandkids.

Six months ago today – right this minute – Senator Mitch McConnell threw me off the Senate floor for reading an old letter from Coretta Scott King about the man Donald Trump had nominated for Attorney General, Jeff Sessions. Mrs. King wrote about the way Sessions had intimidated and prosecuted civil rights workers for helping elderly black citizens to vote. When Senator McConnell and every one of his Republican colleagues kicked me off the Senate floor that night, I went outside to the hallway, pulled out a phone, and read Mrs. King’s letter live on this video. Millions of people heard – or read – Coretta Scott King’s words. They didn't silence us. They made us louder.

Congresswoman Niki Tsongas is more than my colleague - she's a mentor and a friend. She has shown me how tough women fight for families in Massachusetts and across this country. I'll miss Niki when she retires, and the people of Massachusetts will miss her leadership. But I know that Niki's got a lot of fighting left to do until then.

For the last couple of days, I've been in Poland - meeting with American and Polish officials, learning more about U.S. Army operations across eastern Europe, and visiting our troops stationed in Poznan and Powidz. In Powidz yesterday, I also had the privilege of spending time with a unit from Brockton, Massachusetts. Time after time, Poland has been there for the United States - and as Russia continues to engage in aggressive and destabilizing activities in this region, it's more important than ever for our allies like Poland to know ‎that the United States has their backs.

Gen. Paul Selva serves as the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, which means he’s the nation’s second highest-ranking military officer. Last month, he told me that climate change will drive conflict and instability in different ways around the world. Gen. Selva and I agree: climate change is happening, and we must prepare for the profound impact climate change will have on how our military carries out its mission.

In 2007, Estonia decided to move an old bronze statue of a Soviet soldier out from the center of their capital. Vladimir Putin didn't like that very much – and for days afterwards, Estonia was subjected to a mysterious and massive digital siege that crippled its banks, online newspapers, and government websites. Ten years later, Estonia has learned a lot about how to fight back against orchestrated cyber-attacks, and their expertise is critical to the efforts of the United States and our allies to deter and defend against Russian cyber-operations. I spent some time in Estonia this week meeting with top government officials and visiting with military and technical experts at the NATO Cooperative Cyber Defense Center of Excellence to learn more about their work. And I made sure to stop by that statue, too – Estonia may be a tiny country on the front lines of Russian aggression, but the bronze soldier is still nowhere near the center of town.

On my way back to the United States this week, I stopped in Wiesbaden, Germany to visit the headquarters for US Army operations in Europe. During my visit, I had the honor of speaking to a conference of senior military leaders, where I learned more about the US Army's efforts to support NATO and Europe. We reaffirmed the need to strengthen Europe's capabilities against Russia's aggressive and destabilizing activities – its use of separatist forces, cyber-attacks, and propaganda – throughout Europe and the need for the US and NATO to remain united in countering these asymmetric tactics.‎ I'm grateful for the opportunity – and for the chance to grab dinner on the base with a group of soldiers from Massachusetts and their families living in and around Wiesbaden. They represent America's enduring commitment to the security of our European allies and partners and to peace and stability in this important region.

Unions built America’s middle class, and unions will help rebuild it. Last month, I had the chance to talk to a group of bank call-center workers who are fighting to join a union to organize for higher wages and better working conditions. I’m proud to stand shoulder to shoulder with these workers and the Committee for Better Banks because you don’t get what you don’t fight for.
Racism, bigotry and hate are wrong - in Charlottesville and anywhere else in this country. We should be a better people than that.

Someone was murdered at a Neo-Nazi rally today. That happened. In America. In 2017. It's time to make clear where we stand – all of us.  How can President Trump show whose side he's on? He can start by publicly calling this what it is: white supremacy. We make judgments as human beings and as a country about right and wrong. When there's evil, we all need to say it. Especially our President.
Let me be clear: These cowardly acts of hate aren't welcome in Boston or anywhere else in this country.
Looking forward to seeing everyone at our Dartmouth town hall Wednesday night. Hope you can make it!

After 16 years, I am deeply skeptical that a few thousand more troops will enable the Afghans to secure their own country. We should not send more young Americans to risk their lives if we don’t understand exactly where we’re headed and what we’re asking of them.    My trip last month to Afghanistan and Pakistan gave me the chance to see first-hand that the problems in that region cannot be solved by military action alone.  Despite the hard work and sacrifices of our brave servicemembers, the Afghan government now controls less than 60 percent of the country‎. A comprehensive strategy must address corruption, weak popular support for the central government, narco-trafficking that fuels the Taliban, Russian and Iranian support for terrorist and insurgent groups in the region, and a soft border with Pakistan that permits terrorists to move freely and launch attacks on our servicemembers, our Afghan allies, and civilians.  Last night the President promised the American people “a plan for victory," but he failed to identify even the most central problems, much less offer a detailed strategy to deal effectively with them.

Today I was in Fall River with Rep. Bill Keating for a tour of Portugalia, an incredible Portuguese market owned by Michael Benevides and his family. I heard from other small business owners, local elected officials and community leaders about how our government can be better partners for the South Coast (and we ate some terrific cheese).
I'm deeply grateful for the 800 people who packed our UMass Dartmouth town hall tonight and made their voices heard. Thank you!

I love community health centers - and the Greater New Bedford Community Health Center is as good as they get. These dedicated doctors, nurses and health care professionals take incredible care of families of every background. The people I met there yesterday know that health care is a basic human right - and I'm fighting every way I can to support the work of community health centers like this one.
Wow, 1100 people jammed Furnace Brook Middle School for our Marshfield town hall tonight! Thank you all for joining us!

Has your bank ever hit you with a surprise fee on your credit card or checking account? Well, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau just put out a new rule that will help you hold banks accountable for these kinds of charges. Bank lobbyists hate the new CFPB rule, and the Republican Congress is on the verge of reversing the rule and taking away your rights. U.S. Senator Al Franken and I sat down to talk about the rule and what you can do to stop Congress from selling out to the big banks one more time.

We are about to start our town hall at Concord Carlisle High School - and hundreds more are waiting outside and wrapped around the school. I'm heading out to say hello to everyone who didn't make it inside - and thank them for being a part of our democracy.
Tonight's 13th town hall of the year was our biggest yet: 1500 people filled Concord Carlisle High School's auditorium, cafeteria and lawn. THANK YOU!

As a hurricane prepares to devastate Texas, Donald Trump is more concerned with kicking people out of the military and pardoning a racist sherriff who broke the law. Every time we think our President can't go any lower, he goes lower.  I've said it before and I'll say it again: the only thing that matters when it comes to allowing military personnel to serve is whether or not they can handle the job. President Trump just issued an official memo that insults the courage and sacrifices being made by thousands of transgender troops, and he once again proved that he cares more about extreme ideology than military readiness. The President can pretend this decision is about military effectiveness, but it isn't. Banning individuals from serving based on gender identity is shameful and wrong – and it makes America less safe.  Speaking of making America less safe, President Trump and Sheriff Joe Arpaio are two of a kind: both believe the law doesn't apply to them and have used their office to create a platform for racism and bigotry. No one - not Trump and not Arpaio - is above the law.  This is a disgraceful night for President Trump. He has proven that the safety of the American people is the last thing on his mind.

I’m heartsick for the people of Texas right now. Houston is where I lived after I got married at 19. It’s where I graduated from college and where I got my first full-time law-teaching job. It's where I ate the best Tex-Mex ever and where I learned the two-step. It's also where I still have family. When the unthinkable happens, we rely on each other for help, and the victims of Hurricane Harvey – good, hardworking people – need us now. For updates, safety information and details on how you can help first responders and recovery efforts, please visit the American Red Cross Texas Gulf Coast Region website.

I’m proud and grateful for the FEMA volunteers based in Beverly, Massachusetts who are on their way to assist the Gulf Coast. I’m also glad that two Coast Guard helicopters, a plane, and crew from Cape Cod are already helping with Hurricane Harvey rescue efforts. And I’m glad that Boston Mayor Marty Walsh is sending high-water rescue vehicles and cots to help the people of Houston.  The people of the Gulf Coast desperately need our help. Massachusetts will keep doing everything we can to come to their aid.

Unbelievable. Wells Fargo's massive fraud is even worse than we thought. The Federal Reserve should remove every Wells Fargo Board member who served during this scandal. I don't know what they're waiting for.   Congress also can't look the other way. We need the Wells Fargo hearing that Senate Democrats called for ‎earlier this month.
I'm proud of all the men and women in uniform from Massachusetts who are helping with efforts in Houston.

More than 2000 people died of opioid overdoses in Massachusetts last year. It's an epidemic – and it's heartbreaking. Last week, I visited the High Point Treatment Center in Plymouth, an addiction treatment facility that is on the front lines of this fight. High Point estimates that 85% of its funding is from Medicaid, and recent threats in Washington have put the health of countless people here at risk. The providers, staff and patients I spoke to know that we must be doing a whole lot more to expand funding for treatment and access to the life-saving drug naloxone. We must fight for our friends, family and neighbors – because we don't have any other choice. #endoverdose

Education Secretary Betsy DeVos hired a former DeVry official – someone with absolutely no experience enforcing the law – to be the cop in charge of policing sham colleges at the Education Department. This office was literally created last year by the Obama Administration in response to DeVry and other for-profit college’s fraudulent behavior. Is Secretary DeVos just trolling us? This is astounding, and it’s exactly why I launched DeVos Watch to hold her agency accountable.
Happy Labor Day! Today we say loud and clear: Unions built America's middle class, and unions will rebuild America's middle class.

President Trump's record is clear: over and over, he has delivered one sucker punch after another to America's workers. Read my office’s new Labor Day report on how Trump has betrayed America’s working men and women.
Very proud of the Massachusetts Maritime Academy and their officers for stepping up to help our friends and family in the Gulf Coast.

Dreamers are our family, our friends, and our neighbors. They are part of the diverse and beautiful fabric of our nation. In 2012, because of the persistence of many of those Dreamers, we promised them a chance to live, work, learn, and contribute to this country without being ripped away from the only home most of them have ever known. We promised to protect the 800,000 DACA recipients from deportation.   President Trump wants to break that promise by ending DACA. President Trump’s decision to subject Dreamers to mass deportation is part of the bigoted and anti-immigrant policies that have been a cornerstone of his administration. Tu‎rning our backs on Dreamers makes us weaker, makes us less safe, and betrays our values.  America should keep its promises, and if President Trump doesn't know that, then Congress must pass legislation to make the DACA program permanent. We cannot sit back while our family, friends, and neighbors are driven out of their homes. We must fight to protect Dreamers and protect DACA.
I agree, President Obama.
The fight over the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's new forced arbitration rule is about whose side you stand on: big Wall Street banks or military families.

The good news is that we’re finally holding bipartisan meetings in the Senate to talk about how to improve – not completely blow to smithereens – health care in this country. The bad news is that while we’re doing the work in the Senate, President Trump is trying to sabotage the Affordable Care Act so he can say, “I told you so.” We see exactly what he’s up to and we’re going to keep fighting for improvements, not chaos.
Thank you, Attorney General Maura Healey, for fighting for Dreamers in Massachusetts and across this country.

Divide and conquer is an old story in America. Those with money and power have used it time and again to keep us all fighting with each other – over religion, over race, over anything that distracts us from the rigged system that favors those at the very top. Donald Trump loves this tired old playbook. Yesterday, he threw another grenade – this time, at the 800,000 kids whose parents came to our country for a chance to build a better future. Just meet some Dreamers and you’ll see – they’re our kids, our classmates, our teammates. Tonight I introduced three of these kids on the Senate floor – one of them was an intern in my office. There are hundreds of thousands of kids just like them, and we can’t let them down. We must pass the Dream Act now.
Debt-free college for low-income Boston University students leads to a boost in their enrollment! Way to go, BU!
Soldier On is an incredible organization fighting to end veteran homelessness. Very glad to visit their women's program in Leeds today.

It's outrageous that Equifax – a company whose one job is to collect consumer information – failed to safeguard data for 143M Americans. It's also outrageous that Equifax waited so long to disclose the breach – needlessly leaving nearly half of America at risk for a month.  And here’s the real kicker: Equifax is forcing you to give up your right to join a class action lawsuit against the company if you want their credit protection product. That’s right: Equifax fails to protect your data, and then they demand you give up your legal rights to limit the damage they caused.  The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s new rule would stop companies like Equifax from avoiding legal accountability like this – as long as the Republicans don’t reverse it. The Equifax breach is Exhibit A for why we must protect your right to join class actions.
To everyone who wrote emails, tweeted, posted, rallied, and showed up: Thank you! You saved health care in America. Keep it up, we need you in these fights.

The opioid epidemic touches every corner of Massachusetts. I wanted to better understand how we tackle it – so we put together a survey for behavioral health providers and community health centers across the Commonwealth about how we can improve and expand their work. The survey responses showed that Massachusetts is able to provide affordable, innovative care, but there can be long waiting lists for services. They’re stretched too thin. Read my new Boston Globe op-ed about this opioid treatment report – and why we must give addiction treatment providers the tools and support they need to beat this epidemic.

At a recent town hall, lots of hands went up when I asked these Massachusetts residents if they know or love someone who relies on Medicaid. This is the face of health care in America – and these are the folks I’ll continue to fight for as we protect the Affordable Care Act and fight for Medicare for All.
