Congress owes our troops and their families a full debate and effective strategy for the authorization of the use of military force before we send them into harm’s way. But we haven’t been doing that. It’s been 16 years since Congress passed the existing Authorization for Use of Military Force (AUMF) in the first days after the September 11 attacks. To say a lot has changed in the world since 2001 is a massive understatement – but year after year, Congress refuses to re-examine this outdated authority. Senator Rand Paul is fighting for an amendment to the annual defense bill that would repeal the AUMF and give Congress six months to replace it. It’s long past time for Congress to do right by our troops, their families, and the American people, which is why I’m supporting his amendment.

Yesterday in a Banking Committee hearing, these experts told me that the new conflict of interest rule for retirement advisers not only protects consumers -- it's also great for start-ups and even some of the biggest investment companies. The rule shuts down cheating financial advisers, letting honest investors and advisers access new markets. And yet the national Chamber of Commerce is running around like a chicken with its head cut off trying to kill this rule.   Why? Because powerful lobbying groups like the Chamber of Commerce suck down billions of dollars every year in this town, and those dollars don’t keep flowing unless there’s a fight somewhere. So they'll pick one if they have to, whether it makes any sense or not. If I ran one of these companies, I’d take a long hard look at all the shareholder money wasted on membership in the Chamber of Commerce. I think they’re being taken for a ride.
Proud to fight for health care as a basic human right and stand with my colleagues who support Bernie's Medicare for All bill. Tune in here at 2pm.
Health care is a basic human right – and it’s time to fight for it. Tune in live as I join Senator Bernie Sanders for the official announcement of his Medicare for All bill.

I come from a long line of fighters in Massachusetts who have said, over and over, that health care is a basic human right. That’s why I am proud to support Bernie’s Medicare for All bill to expand access to every American.
They didn’t call Senator Kennedy “the lion of the Senate” for nothing. He fought for health care for American families his entire life.

When the Republicans tried to repeal health care coverage from more than 20 million Americans, folks like Massachusetts Blue Cross Blue Shield fought for their customers – but not health insurance giant Anthem. Even though more than half of Anthem’s revenue comes from government health care programs, Anthem sent Congress a ransom note: Give us bigger tax cuts and more giveaways or we’ll pull out of more state health care exchanges. Today I told an Anthem VP: If they want to keep making huge profits from taxpayer money, they ought to be able to provide decent coverage through the ACA.

Lots of people are outraged about the Equifax data breach. I am too. Here’s what I’ve been doing about it this week:  1. I Introduced the Freedom from Equifax Exploitation (FREE) Act with Senator Brian Schatz. Our bill gives you more control of your data. Companies like Equifax make billions selling access to your data without your consent, then charge you if you want to stop them. It's nuts. The FREE Act lets you freeze – and unfreeze – access to your credit file at no cost. It's like a free Do Not Call list for your credit data. The idea behind our bill is simple: Equifax doesn't pay you when they sell your data. You shouldn't have to pay them to stop selling it.      2. I also reintroduced the Equal Employment for All Act to prevent employers from asking job applicants for their credit histories. Credit reports are already riddled with errors. The Equifax hack will make it worse. Inaccurate reports shouldn't hurt your job chances. Bad credit doesn’t make you a bad employee. Workers should compete on the merits, not on their credit scores.  3. On top of these bills, I launched investigation into the Equifax breach & credit reporting industry in general. I sent letters to Equifax, the other credit reporting agencies, regulators, and the GAO to figure out how we can reform this broken industry.  The bills and letters this week are just the beginning to hold Equifax accountable. In the meantime, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has a helpful guide to protect yourself.

Veterans who have the training and experience to operate heavy trucks and buses in combat zones have the skills needed to drive trucks on our highways. I wrote a bipartisan bill with Senator John Cornyn to remove legal obstacles that delay service members from getting commercial drivers’ licenses. I’m glad that the Senate passed our Jobs for Heroes Act yesterday and hope that the House will pass it soon. This bill will help veterans looking for good jobs and will help employers looking for talented employees.

Yesterday, I called out Anthem – one of the nation’s largest health insurers – for abandoning people in a number of states simply because Congress won’t make it easier for them to squeeze huge profits out of patients. Today, they’ve sheepishly announced that they’re partially reversing their decision to leave Virginia. That’s great – but health insurance companies making loads of profits off taxpayers shouldn’t need to be shamed into providing coverage to people who need it. It’s time for reform.
NA

The Port of Boston has been vital to our economy since the colonial era. But we need to invest in our infrastructure for it to succeed in the long run. That's why I was happy to join today's kickoff celebration of the Boston Harbor Dredging Project – deepening the harbor to allow bigger ships and more container traffic. This project will create jobs, improve the efficient passage of goods, and improve the long-term economic competitiveness of the Port of Boston.
This is good news. At least for now, President Trump and Attorney General Jeff Sessions can’t bludgeon towns into complying with dumb and dangerous ICE policies.

One of the best ways to make our economy stronger, families more prosperous, and future brighter is to invest in kids, but for too many Americans, affordable, high-quality child care is increasingly out of reach. I’m glad to join my Democratic colleagues in introducing the Child Care for Working Families Act, which would help ensure that all families have access to child care and preschool.‎ Unlike The White House’s plan, whose benefits are targeted at wealthy households, this proposal ensures that no family has to make the impossible choice between making a living and caring for their little one.

The Senate Republicans have a big 9/30 deadline to repeal the Affordable Care Act. And here's the scary thing: they might have the votes to do it.   ‎There's nothing new and improved about the Graham-Cassidy “health care” bill – it's the same cruel Republican “health care” bill, but on steroids. Graham-Cassidy cuts Medicaid funding and rolls back protections for people with preexisting conditions. It completely eliminates help for families to buy health insurance. ‎Gone. Good luck on your own. Coverage ripped away from tens of millions of Americans – kids with disabilities, grandparents in nursing homes.  Let me be repeat: The Graham-Cassidy "health care" bill IS Trumpcare, and it will rip health care away from millions of Americans. The fight to save heath care isn't over. Sound the alarm. We need you to fight today and every day until this bill is dead.
My thoughts are with the Marseille acid attack victims, who are reportedly Boston College students. My office has reached out to BC to help the students however we can.
Happy 70th Birthday, US Air Force! I was happy to celebrate last week by speaking with Senior Airman Schultz of Springfield, Massachusetts - now deployed to SW Asia.

Senate Republicans have until 9/30 to repeal the Affordable Care Act with just 50 votes – and they just might have the votes to do it. But make no mistake: their Cassidy-Graham bill is just another version of the same old heartless “health care” plan that they’ve tried to jam down our throats for the past eight months. Tonight I’m joining Senate Democrats on the floor to fight (again) to save millions of Americans’ health care. Watch live now.
RED ALERT: Trumpcare is not dead.

Earlier this year, Senator Susan Collins and I introduced the Jessica Kensky and Patrick Downes Act. I’m glad the defense bill just passed by the Senate includes a similar provision that will help victims of terrorism get the expert medical care they need. Thanks to Boston residents Jessica and Patrick for championing this idea and bringing it to the finish line – your story inspires me every day.

After hackers stole the personal information of 143 million Americans, Equifax hid the breach from consumers for more than a month, failed to clearly inform people whether their information had been stolen, then tried to profit off the breach by tricking people into signing up for a costly credit monitoring product that also required them to give up their legal rights. Wow.  The bottom line is that companies like Equifax are making billions of dollars a year collecting, sharing, and selling highly personal information about you – all without your explicit permission or without paying you a penny. That’s why I introduced the FREE Act to level the playing field for consumers. I hope my colleagues will work with me to pass this bill and give consumers back control of their personal credit data.

You might think, after months and months of failed attempts to repeal the Affordable Care Act, the Republicans would have come to their senses. But no – the latest Cassidy-Graham proposal is another version of the same terrible set of policies, with a fresh coat of paint and a new name.

A year ago today, I told then-CEO of Wells Fargo John Stumpf he should resign, face criminal and civil investigation, and return every nickel he made during his bank’s fake accounts scandal.  Anything short of that wouldn’t be real accountability for his leading role in this giant scam.    John Stumpf lost his job and forfeited millions of dollars in compensation, but I’m still fighting for accountability at Wells Fargo.  There still needs to be a full civil and criminal investigation.  I’ve pushed the Federal Reserve to use its legal authority to remove all 12 members of the Wells Board of Directors who served during the fake accounts scandal.  And I’ve asked for another hearing with the new CEO of Wells Fargo, so we can get some answers about all the new frauds coming out of the bank.     Here’s my bottom line: until big bank executives and Board members are held personally accountable for massive frauds, these consumer scams will never stop.
Whether it’s Equifax or Wells Fargo, senior executives need to be held accountable if we want to stop corporate conduct that hurts millions of working families.

MGH Chelsea Healthcare Center keeps our families healthy and strengthens our community. The doctors, nurses, health professionals and patients that I visited today know what repealing the Affordable Care Act and gutting Medicaid would mean to our families in Massachusetts. I told them today: The Republicans’ Graham-Cassidy “health care” bill is just the same set of terrible policies with a fresh coat of paint. I’m doing everything I can to fight back – but we need lots of people speaking up again and making their voices heard.

The judges who sit on our courts should have one mission: to provide equal justice under law. But President Trump and his Republican allies are using every tool they can to tilt our courts in favor of the wealthy and well-connected. Their latest trick is to flout the precedent of consulting home-state senators on nominees to serve on courts in their states. Even worse, they want Democrats to submit blue slips that rubber-stamp their pro-corporate, right-wing nominees to advance. It’s insulting.  I stand with U.S. Senator Al Franken and other Democrats in saying no – we won’t help Trump and the Republicans bypass the process and stack our courts with pro-corporate, right-wing judges.

For weeks, Democrats and Republicans have been participating in a bipartisan process focused on stabilizing the insurance markets and lowering premiums. But now Republicans are turning their backs on that process and throwing away weeks of bipartisan work so they can embrace the “Graham-Cassidy” proposal, which will rip health care from millions of Americans. And the scary thing is they may have the votes. So we must fight back and protect health care in America. Again.

The fight to protect Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act is a fight for life and death for people who need opioid addiction treatment. Instead of working to help communities battling the opioid epidemic, Republicans want to vote next week on a cruel health care bill that would gut health care coverage for millions of people battling addiction. It’s time for us to get on offense.
We must keep the pressure on to make sure this disaster of a bill isn’t passed next week.

These doctors say cutting Medicaid would be a disaster for our country’s kids and mothers. Senate Republicans: before you vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act next week, listen to the doctors in your state begging you not to.

Senate Republicans are holding their only hearing on their latest bill to destroy health care for millions of Americans – right now, in the middle of the day on a Monday, betting that you won’t watch. Watch live now and show the Senate Republicans: We believe that health care is a basic human right. We’re watching – and we’re fighting back.
I’m joining the team at Indivisible live right now to talk about why we must kill the Republicans’ Graham-Cassidy bill and save health care for millions of Americans. Tune in!

The Republicans are hoping that while you’re distracted by the possibility of millions of people losing health care, and the devastating hurricane damage in Puerto Rico, and the President’s reckless game of chicken with North Korea and fighting with the NFL, that you won’t notice when they take away your legal right to take big banks like Wells Fargo and giant corporations like Equifax to court when they cheat you. This vote could happen as soon as tomorrow – we need all hands on deck right now to fight back.
Red alert: this vote could happen as soon as tomorrow.

The Senate has real work to do. On September 30th, federal programs like CHIP, Community Health Centers, teaching health centers, and a whole package of Medicare and Medicaid programs will run out of funding. Hospitals and doctors who are serving their communities will simply run out of money. So while Republicans are yelling and screaming about repealing Obamacare, they’re creating a crisis that isn’t getting much attention. There are four days until the September 30th funding deadline – Republican leadership needs to do its job and fund these health programs.

I've called for Equifax executives to be held legally accountable for their role in failing to stop this data breach and hiding it from the public for forty days. It's not real accountability if the Chairman and CEO resigns without giving back a nickel in pay, publicly answering questions, or facing a full civil investigation. It’s also not real accountability if the guy promoted to Chairman is an Equifax board member who served on the committee that was responsible for overseeing data security when this massive data breach occurred.   Former Chairman and CEO Smith, along with the new Chairman and the new interim CEO, should all testify before the Senate Banking Committee. It’s the least they can do. The American public deserve answers about what went wrong at Equifax and what the company plans to do going forward.

The fundamental problem with NAFTA is simple: the agreement doesn't work for American workers. Despite promising to fix NAFTA's problems, President Trump and his Administration have failed to fight for workers through the first three rounds. They have failed to get rid of ISDS - the corporate courts in NAFTA that give big businesses their own special rights. And now they are reportedly proposing NAFTA provisions that do nothing to bring back American jobs.     I wrote to the Trump Administration demanding the removal of ISDS from NAFTA. I also wrote a bill with Senator Sherrod Brown and Senator Kirsten Gillibrand to stop states from restricting workers' right to unionize and fight for fair wages. We should look out for families - not corporations.  President Trump isn't following through on his promise to fix NAFTA and boost working families. It's time for Congress to take action.

We know Republicans aren’t done trying to gut health care – but when we’re fighting for people’s lives, we don’t get tired. So bring it on. We’ll be there. We’ll be loud, we’ll be strong, and we’ll fight for what we believe in. THANK YOU for being in this fight.

I’m very glad that we have stopped the Republicans from throwing millions of people off of their health care. But we have another urgent humanitarian crisis in America that Congress needs to address RIGHT NOW. Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands have been devastated by Hurricanes Irma and Maria. The entire island of Puerto Rico is without power indefinitely. Thousands of families are homeless. Critical infrastructure is crumbling, and distribution of relief supplies has been painfully slow and difficult.   These millions of American citizens will need a huge amount of immediate disaster relief and long-term support to recover – far more than they have received so far. Today I joined my Democratic colleagues in calling for Congress to pass an appropriations bill immediately to help the people of Puerto Rico and the US Virgin islands, and last week I also joined colleagues in requesting that the federal government fully fund the disaster response. The Americans who reside on Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands need to know their federal government has not forgotten them and is doing everything it can to aid them.
I'm glad to stand shoulder to shoulder with Senator Edward J. Markey to fight for the people of Puerto Rico.

The Republicans may vote THIS WEEK to repeal the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s rule that allows you to take big banks like Wells Fargo and giant corporations like Equifax to court when they cheat you. I’m joining Senate Democrats live right now to speak out in support of the CFPB’s forced arbitration rule and oppose the Republicans’ big bank giveaway.

The NLRB may be the most important independent federal agency you’ve never heard of. When Congress created the National Labor Relations Board, they gave it a simple mission—encourage collective bargaining. But instead of nominating people who will fulfill this mission, President Trump has stacked the board with anti-worker, big money insiders.   This week, the Senate confirmed William Emanuel to the final seat on the five-member board. In more than four decades practicing law, Mr. Emanuel has never been on the side of workers. Mr. Emanuel has every right to spend his career representing corporations. But a guy who has never ever even once represented workers should not serve on the NLRB. Period. Now that the board is stacked against workers, we’ll have to stay vigilant as unionizing efforts come under attack in the years to come.

The “new” Republican tax plan is the same warmed-over, trickle-down plan they’ve been pushing for decades. It delivers massive tax cuts to millionaires and giant corporations and kicks working families to the curb. While the plan slashes the income tax rate for the highest earners, it actually increases the income tax rate that applies to many working families. The plan gets rid of the state and local tax deduction that millions of working families rely on, while repealing the estate tax that applies only to a handful of the wealthiest families in the country. And the plan will explode the deficit, which – I guarantee you – will lead Republicans to turn around and say we need to gut Medicaid, Medicare, and investments in infrastructure, research, and education.   Not one penny in tax cuts for the wealthy and giant corporations – especially not on the backs of everyone else. We will fight back against this GOP tax plan.

Two years ago today, I gave a speech at the Edward M. Kennedy Institute that I’d wanted to give for a long time – confronting the ugly reality of racism and injustice in America. Now a man who calls African Americans “thugs” is the President of the United States – and a man who was too racist to become a judge in the 1980s runs the Department of Justice. We must not be silent. We must continue to fight – to make the “necessary trouble” for progress.

Powerful interests invested vast sums of money into confirming judges who will tilt our courts in favor of billionaires and big businesses. When the Republicans stole a Supreme Court seat from President Obama and forced Trump nominee Neil Gorsuch through the Senate, they knew their investment would pay off. Today it has. The Supreme Court has announced that it will consider Janus v. AFSCME, a case that could defund unions for teachers, police officers, firefighters, and postal workers. The Republican-appointed majority is poised to deal the knock-out blow to public sector unions, tilting the playing field even further in favor of corporations, and making it that much harder for workers to join together and stand up for themselves.

Market competition is dying in America – but Makan Delrahim, who spent over a decade lobbying for giant mergers on behalf of powerful companies, is President Trump’s choice to lead the Justice Department’s Antitrust Division. If we want Washington to stop working for the armies of corporate lobbyists and start working for the American people again, then the Senate needs to start rejecting nominees like Mr. Delrahim.

President Trump should nominate a new Secretary of Health and Human Services who is less focused on booking luxury travel and ripping health insurance away from millions of Americans – and more focused on actually protecting and improving the health and well-being of families.

Puerto Rico was already suffering from an economic crisis long before it got hit by the hurricane. Now it faces another humanitarian crisis. With every day that passes, I’m more outraged that the federal government isn’t doing much, much more to help our fellow Americans in Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands. And every day, I get more and more calls from people in Holyoke, Springfield, Worcester, Fitchburg, Southbridge, Boston, and across Massachusetts who are desperately worried about the people they love.    Today I met with community leaders, local elected officials, and concerned citizens in Worcester and Springfield, and listened to the stories of people whose family members are struggling to survive in Puerto Rico. Congress must immediately take up an appropriations bill to come to Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands’ aid – and President Trump should use his authority to more quickly and comprehensively respond to the disaster. These Americans need us.

President Trump’s National Security Advisor pled guilty to a federal crime relating to his contacts with the Russian Government. This is not normal. This is not fake news. This is a serious threat to the national security of the United States. Flynn’s admission underscores the importance of the Special Prosecutor. No one is above the law – NO ONE. The American people deserve to know the truth.
No, I haven’t had time to read the 500-page #GOPTaxScam bill that we’re voting on tonight. I couldn’t read it if I tried – and I did.
The Senate Republicans are about to try to ram through their #GOPTaxScam bill. Tune in live.
The Senate Republicans are trying to ram through their #GOPTaxScam bill in the middle of the night. Tune in live.

This Congress doesn’t work for working families. It works for corporate lobbyists and campaign donors in backroom deals and 1:30 AM votes. This corruption is hollowing out America’s middle class and tearing down our democracy. Working families are already on the ropes – and this tax scam is another punch in the gut. We must keep fighting back with everything we’ve got to stop them from delivering the knockout blow.   Tonight the Senate Republicans gave a giant tax break to the rich and left everyone else holding the bag. This is about more than economics – it’s about our values. The Republicans just proved they are morally bankrupt.

Our government must take swift, decisive action to stop the opioid epidemic. But President Trump still hasn’t taken steps to work with Congress to get the funding we need – or filled leadership positions that are critical to fighting this crisis. Instead, he has relied on Kellyanne Conway – a political pundit with no public health experience – to lead the White House’s opioid crisis response. Today, I pushed the White House for details on Ms. Conway’s role and its plans to address the opioid epidemic. More than 90 Americans die every day from opioid overdoses, and the American people deserve answers.

We shouldn’t have an education secretary who doesn’t believe in public education. We shouldn’t have an EPA director who doesn’t believe in climate change. And we shouldn’t have a CFPB director who doesn’t believe in consumer protection. Watch as I explain how the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau guards consumers against bad financial products – and why we must stop Donald Trump’s efforts to undermine it.

A bunch of senators – including some Democrats – are trying to roll back the rules for big banks that sucked down nearly $50 billion in taxpayer-funded bailouts a few years ago. It’s insane. Today the Senate Banking Committee will be debating and revising this terrible #BankLobbyistsAct. Watch live as I fight for a dozen amendments to put the American people first.

Bruce and I love hiking in Massachusetts and all over the country. We haven’t had a chance to hike Bears Ears – but we did visit Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument during a trip to Bryce Canyon years ago. It was a great hike out to a gorgeous waterfall that dropped into a pool. On the trek back, we huddled under an incredible rock overhang while a hailstorm blew through.   Yesterday, President Trump drastically cut the size of Bears Ears National Monument by 85%, and shrank Grand Staircase-Escalante by more than half. These are beautiful lands rich in natural, cultural, and historic value that our children and grandchildren deserve a chance to enjoy and explore. But President Trump is more interested in giving another massive handout to big corporations that don’t like to be told a piece of land is off-limits for drilling or excavation. Let President Trump know that our children deserve better.

Today the Senate Banking Committee will be debating and revising this terrible #BankLobbyistsAct. Watch live as I fight for a dozen amendments to put the American people first.

The fight for stronger competition is similar to the fights over health care or tax reform or the other big issues. These fights are about what kind of country we’re building: one that works only for the wealthy and powerful, or one that works for all of us. Watch live as I speak to the Open Markets Institute this morning about how competition makes our economy – and our country – stronger.

The federal government will run out of money on Friday unless Congress passes a new spending bill. This isn’t just about keeping the lights on - it’s about our values. Democrats want Republicans to do their jobs. That mean working to keep the government open, it means passing the Dream Act, and it means renewing expired funding for community health centers and for the Children’s Health Insurance Program. U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders and I are talking about things Democrats are fighting for in this spending bill that would make a big difference to working families. Watch live now.

It hasn’t even been a week since Senate Republicans voted to hand $1.5 trillion in tax giveaways over to billionaires and giant corporations, and Paul Ryan is already saying that Republicans want to cut Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid next year because “that’s really where the problem lies, fiscally speaking.”  In other words: “Sorry!” There’s no more money for the things that help American families.   Wealthy Republican donors might support this shameless attack on seniors, people with disabilities, and working families, but the American people don’t. These people aren't stashing their Social Security checks in the Cayman Islands and buying vacation homes in Aruba – they are hanging on by their fingernails to their place in the middle class. We will not let the Republicans use tax giveaways for the rich as an excuse to break our promises to working people. We have to do everything we can to stop this corrupt tax bill.
The future of 800k Dreamers hangs in the balance. Millions of kids at risk of losing their health insurance. Pass a clean Dream Act. Reauthorize CHIP. Let’s quit kicking the can down the road.

Funding for kids' health insurance and community health centers expired over two months ago. Massachusetts health advocates wrote me a letter last week, saying Congress must take action. Kids and families across the state can't wait any longer: "Urgent action to reauthorize funding for both programs is necessary to provide certainty for both families and state budgets in Massachusetts and across the nation."​​

As Congress figures out a budget for next year, Bernie and I got together to discuss what Washington should do for all Americans – like invest in child care and mental health, save multiemployer pensions, strengthen student loan forgiveness for public servants, and take care of our veterans and seniors. The vast majority of Americans support this, but Republicans are focused on corporate tax cuts instead. Republican leadership should stop listening to their wealthy donors and start working for the American people, so we can pass a budget that actually helps workers and their families.

For years, Republicans have worked hand-in-hand with billionaire-funded right-wing groups to ensure that our courts advance the interests of the wealthy and powerful over those of everybody else. Now that there’s a Republican President who’s committed to tilting our courts further in favor of the rich and the powerful, Republicans are looking to fill our courts with judges who share that commitment. This week, the GOP-controlled Senate will vote on the nominations of Steven Grasz, Donny Willett, and James Ho to sit on the federal courts of appeals. Grasz is one of the few nominees to be rated “not qualified” by the American Bar Association, and the records of all three nominees show that they will favor powerful interests over workers, women, LGBTQ individuals, people of color, and religious minorities. We need to fight for judges that protect the rights of all Americans, not just the wealthy and the well-connected. That’s why I will be voting against these nominees, and I urge my colleagues to do the same.

Mitch McConnell wants to delay seating Alabama’s new senator – Democrat Doug Jones – until after the Republicans jam through a final vote on their tax scam. When Massachusetts shocked the country and elected a Republican to the Senate seat Ted Kennedy had held for years, Democrats delayed a final vote on the Affordable Care Act until after Scott Brown was seated. The GOP should listen to the people of Alabama, respect the democratic process, and do the same now.

Net neutrality matters. A lot. Tomorrow, the Federal Communications Commission is expected to eliminate protections that keep the internet free, fair and open to everyone – paving the way for giant internet companies to block access and charge more. FCC Chairman Ajit Pai has barreled full speed ahead despite disturbing reports that potentially tens of thousands of comments submitted during the public comment period were fake. The vast majority of Americans support net neutrality and are being silenced. We must fight to defend an internet that is fair and open to all.

My message to Mitch McConnell is simple: No vote on the Republican tax bill before Doug Jones takes his rightful seat in the US Senate. The seating of Doug Jones won’t give him or Democrats the power to block the tax bill, or any other piece of legislation. But it will respect the people of Alabama, their choice, and our democratic process. #NoJonesNoVote

In every corner of our economy, big and powerful corporations are choking off competition. These mergers and acquisitions don’t just control our airlines or banks or cable companies – they also impact the food we eat. This year alone, the Trump administration has already approved two major agribusiness mergers – and now Monsanto and Bayer are seeking approval to join forces too. That’s right: a gigantic chemical and pesticide company wants to merge with a gigantic GMO seed company to create a mega-gigantic company that would control a quarter of all the world’s seeds and pesticides. These mergers stomp all over family farmers and give big companies an iron grip on the nation’s food supply. But it doesn’t have to work like this. The Department of Justice should listen to small farmers and consumers and not allow corporate agribusiness to call all the shots.

The FCC just voted to hand control of the internet over to giant internet companies, but this isn’t over. Congress must step up to repeal this rule, restore net neutrality protections, and defend a fair and open internet.

Five years ago today, twenty children and six women were killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School. Catherine Hubbard had beautiful bright red hair and adored animals. Jack Pinto was a born Giants fan and athlete. James Mattioli loved to sing at the top of his lungs. Emilie Parker always had art supplies with her, so she could hand-make cards for people she met. They all would have been middle schoolers this year. Congress still hasn’t passed a single bill to stop these mass shootings and protect our children since that terrible tragedy in Newtown. It’s long past time for us to act.

Mitch McConnell’s hypocrisy is on full display this week. In 2010, when Massachusetts Senator Scott Brown – a Republican – won a special election, McConnell called on President Obama and the Senate Democrats to halt any votes on the Affordable Care Act. And President Obama and the Democrats listened. They seated Brown in the Senate before calling a final vote on health care – even though it was inconvenient. Even though it risked failure of their health care bill. But today, Mitch McConnell wants to charge full-steam ahead on his tax bill before newly-elected Senator Doug Jones gets seated. Why? Because Doug is a Democrat. This is playing politics at its worst. It’s not only hypocritical – it’s undemocratic.

Make no mistake: the tax bill is not just about numbers. It’s about people like Ady, his wife Rachael, and their son Carl. Ady was recently diagnosed with ALS – and the Republican tax bill threatens the Medicare program Ady relies on, all so that billionaires and giant corporations can get massive tax breaks they don’t need. What does that say about our values? I’ll be fighting this tax scam to the bitter end – and need you to join me.

Many moms have a child care story that sounds a lot like mine. Juggling a growing family while also holding a teaching job was tough as nails. Without child care – and my Aunt Bee who moved in with my family – I was a goner. The challenge of finding reliable, affordable child care is a huge boulder for parents. That’s why I’m fighting for a down payment on universal child care to be included in our end-of-year budget.

The task in front of Congress over the coming week boils down to a basic question: Who does Washington work for? If Republicans were serious about providing relief for the middle class, they'd stop trying to ram through tax cuts for corporations and sit down with Democrats to pass a budget that respects American workers. Take a look at what Democrats in the Senate believe our nation should invest in.

Congressional Republicans want to spend this week delivering tax breaks to the billionaires and giant corporations that fund their campaigns. But we have a list of things to do before the holiday break that’s a mile long. We need to keep our promise to 800,000 Dreamers. We need to renew funding for children’s health insurance. And we also have to pass another government funding bill so the lights stay on past Friday.   Rather than lurching from crisis to crisis and focusing on helping those at the top, Congress has a real chance to invest in working families this week. Read my op-ed with Bernie Sanders in today’s New York Times, where we make the case for a few ways that Congress could work for all of us.

I love visiting our incredible community health centers across Massachusetts. They adapt to their neighborhoods to provide critical care at lower costs for anyone who walks through their doors. But Congress blew past the September 30th deadline to fund our community health centers – and now they’re facing impossible choices to keep the doors open. Read my new STAT op-ed on why Congress should reauthorize funding for community health centers right now. This should be a no-brainer.

The internet doesn’t belong to big internet companies. It belongs to all of us. Read my op-ed in the New Bedford Standard-Times on why people across Massachusetts and around the country should fight the FCC’s decision to kill net neutrality.

While House Republicans are set to vote tomorrow on a massive tax giveaway to giant corporations and billionaires, they are also gearing up to vote on a bill that would roll back the rules on dozens of the biggest banks in the country. These banks sucked down almost $70 billion in taxpayer bailouts just a few years ago – and now Republicans want to turn them loose all over again. No Democrat that claims to support working families should join Republicans in supporting this bill.

Today’s the day Congress votes on the final tax bill – one that is overwhelmingly unpopular around the country. But Congress these days isn’t listening to the people it's supposed to represent. It’s listening to big money. The last time Kansas put the interests of influential donors over the interests of regular people, the economy tanked and public schools had to close. But instead of learning from the terrible tax policy enacted in Kansas, Republicans in Congress want to replicate it nationwide. And, as happened in Kansas, it will have devastating effects for years to come.

The #GOPTaxScam is shameful – and it’s the result of a shameful process. Tune in live as I speak on the Senate floor one last time before the Republicans ram through a vote on this terrible bill tonight.

No, there isn’t “plenty of time” to pass the Dream Act. 30,000 Dreamers will lose their legal status each month. The Dreamers I just spoke with outside the Capitol can’t wait any longer for Congress to keep its promise. We need the #DreamActNow.

Donors and corporate shareholders are popping champagne bottles tonight as the Republicans ram through their tax bill. It’s shameful – and people are right to be angry. But to everyone who made calls, wrote letters, and showed up in person: Thank you. Stay in this fight – we need you.

The bill that the Republicans jammed through the Senate tonight isn’t tax reform. It’s a heist. Let's call this out for what it is: Government for sale.   Americans are angry. And they are right to be angry. Over and over, again and again, they watch this Congress ignore their problems while jumping to do more favors for billionaires, giant companies, and campaign donors.  Sooner or later, a reckoning is coming. And I will promise you this: When it does, the politicians who lead this Congress and voted for this tax heist will be held accountable for turning their backs on the American people.
People are angry about the #GOPTaxScam – and they are right to be. I am, too.

Dreamers have been active at the Capitol this week – urging Senators to vote on a clean Dream Act before we all leave for the holidays. I’m right there with them – we can’t let 800,000 young people, brought to the US as kids, live in fear every day that they will be ripped apart from their family and friends to be deported to a country they barely know. Senator McConnell: what are you waiting for? Hold a vote. #DreamActNow

When sleazy for-profit colleges like ITT Tech and Corinthian Colleges break the law and cheat students, the law says these defrauded students can get their entire student loan cancelled. But after almost a year of inaction – and with over 100,000 defrauded students waiting for answers – Betsy DeVos found a way to do as little as possible to help as few students as possible. Betsy DeVos’ stingy and ridiculous scheme for making many of these students and veterans pay the federal government money they do not owe is just shameful.
Congress should not go home until we keep our promise to help the 800k Dreamers. Heading to the Senate floor to urge my colleagues to pass a clean #DreamActNow.

I voted no tonight on a continuing resolution that does not include the #DreamActNow. Congress shouldn’t leave town to celebrate the holidays with our families while 800,000 Dreamers fear being ripped apart from their families and deported to a country they barely know. We must keep our promise.

Workers have the right to keep their medical information private from their employers. But until recently, a federal rule allowed companies to slap their employees with a 30% penalty on their health insurance premiums if they refused to turn over their medical records as part of a “voluntary” wellness program. This month, a court struck down this discriminatory federal rule and said employers can’t impose these penalties while the rule is being rewritten. As the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission gets to work on rewriting the rule on wellness programs, I’ll be watching closely to make sure it doesn’t violate anti-discrimination laws.
